Good question. I should document how this two params work. For ostree/atomic  usage, we're not expecting both of the 2 params are passed in. Generally, there should be only one params being set.

For atomic host deploy, it's expecting a commit ID, which means a small upgrade, but still in current branch. e.g from Fedora Atomic 27.100 to Fedora Atomic 27.122. In other words.

For atomic host rebase, it's expecting a remote/branch name, e.g. fedora-atomic-29 as the code above. For this case, it means user can upgrade from a different branch/remote, say from Fedora Atomic 28 to Fedora Atomic 29.

charms_openstack/adapters.py.message: I'm slightly concerned about the blanket enablement of this feature across all charms that use charms.openstack - does this have general applicability or is the warning that this resolves something specific to gnocchi?

Hi James,

Thank you for the helpful comment because it led to a better investigation on binary_prefix argument.

I found out that this argument was introduced to PyMySQL version 0.8 and later in order to change the behavior of PyMySQL regarding bytes/bytearray. They initially introduced it before 0.8 as the default behavior [1] and later they made it optional because of compatibility issues with other packages which consume PyMySQL (e.g. Django, SQLAlchemy)

Setting this argument for every OpenStack charm is indeed risky but this was happening already for the period between the initial introduction and the commit that made it optional. Speaking about Gnocchi, this change indeed fixes the warnings about invalid utf8 character strings we receive to our OpenStack deployment.

If you think this should not be here I could create a class to override DatabaseRelationAdapter get_uri method directly to Gnocchi charm and use it instead [2]. 

[1] https://github.com/PyMySQL/mysqlclient-python/pull/106
[2] https://github.com/openstack/charm-gnocchi/blob/master/src/lib/charm/openstack/gnocchi.py#L87

mariadb/templates/bin/_backup_mariadb.sh.message: Why is this adjustment necessary? Is the date being passed in correctly? Shouldn't we aim to fix the incorrect arguments (wherever it originates).

> The calculation is an integer division and any time less than a day
 > is rounded to 0.

You already have a seconds difference, why not just convert the "MARIADB_DAYS_TO_KEEP" into seconds? Then it's just a simple comparison, and you won't have any rounding errors.

The calculation is an integer division and any time less than a day is rounded to 0. Here, one second less than 24 hours is added to the time, such that any time more than 3 days will be counted as passed 3 days
The date in the filename is used to avoid that the last touched time is not the backup time

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Can you provide more details here? What is the bug and how does this fix it?

Correct, the marker is the last seen item in the last page:

https://developer.openstack.org/api-guide/compute/paginated_collections.html
Excellent commit message, explains the problem well. Thank you.

nova/objects/build_request.py.message: A comment here would be good. I'll add that.

Indeed, we need to return the next item after the marker as the first item, so adding one to the marker_index does that.

Here's how we get instances when providing a marker, calling utils.paginate_query in oslo.db:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/93597864a36e69bdf5d8c83e49783ca081017e32/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L2236-L2240

and paginate_query returns the next item found after the marker (linked to docstring, you can also look at code):

https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/f1be3e74a6c8b28c7ef77ce6ee8808364b02b2a7/oslo_db/sqlalchemy/utils.py#L170-L171

And we're sure we can't get an IndexError here somehow?

What if len(sorted_build_reqs) is 1 and the single entry is the marker? In that case, limit_index would start at 1 on L453. Let's say the limit is 1000 (the default). Then:

limit_index = marker_index + limit

Makes limit_index = 1 + 1000 = 1001

And then:

            if limit_index > len_build_reqs:  # 1001 > 1
                limit_index = len_build_reqs

So we are left with limit_index = 1.

Then we do: sorted_build_reqs[marker_index:limit_index]

So sorted_build_reqs[1:1] right? Which leaves us with [], so yeah I guess that's correct.
Is there some reason we don't check for a marker here? Did we miss this?
Oh nevermind I missed the "and not marker" condition.

The reason should be updated as we are now keeping it until neutron sriov agent does not depend on mac address.

maybe reference:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1841067

From what i see in the code, this happens as nova virt driver attempts to "recreate" libvirt nodev name from the current state of the system in: virt.libvrit.driver.LibvirtDriver._get_pcinet_info()

So, Ideally if no one except libvirt changes the mac address all is fine, BUT unfortunately that's not the case.

Alternatively we could have fetched all nodev and search for the netdevice name without the mac which would have removed the mac address dependency altogether.

that is not the only reason but yes.

ranger/templates/deployment-ranger-servi.message: im not familiar enough with ranger, but are there cases where we would not want the services pod to be killed when not every endpoint is returning 'ok'?

Ranger pod has multiple processes, each provides the endpoint.  Ideally, it would be good to restart the process in a pod instead of restarting the pod itself.  However, after some testing, it is not possible to delete individual process without creating a corresponding defunct process.  In addition, the log for the new process also does not come out when doing kubernetes logs.  Therefore, we abandoned restarting a single process.  In the near future, some re-architecture is needed to implement either a supervisor process or each process has its own pod.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: The first line should be limited to 50 characters

I know that it _should_ be wrapped to 50 chars, but I think that readability is more important: I cannot condense the message into 50 chars (periodic + reclaim + deleted + instances is about 30 chars).

See my comment in the bug report, it's trying to lazy-load some values I think which needs to reload the entire instance from the database with some joined table probably, and because the instance is deleted we get the InstanceNotFound. If we loaded up those instances with the joined tables from the beginning, we might not hit that problem.
What circumstances? That's the question I have inline, i.e. how do I recreate this?

I do not know, but I have seen this in our production OpenStack (and in other deployments as well). For some unknown reason, sometimes, the instances were not properly deleted. I do not have the time to check why this is happening, and I cannot tell you how to reproduce this.

However, as I said in the but report, I am abandoning this patchset as now I can consider the bug as a wont-fix (this is not happening anymore for new instances).

> However, as I said in the but report, I am abandoning this patchset

OK, fair enough. I was not aware of its existence, thanks for the pointer.

I think we should actually put a limit on this query.

In an old cloud that has lots of failed soft_deleted cleanups, and they have not pruned their DB, this list could be quite big.

I wouldn't mention it, but I have seen this cause OOM killing of nova-compute processes in a related situation in the past.
I do agree, I will put a number number here.
Nit: I would say its tempting for line 6523 to be put inside this try/except clause, in case that ever starts failing for a different reason, and kills the loop. But thats a separate change really.
Where does it actually fail? The bug report isn't clear on this. Is it here? Or later?

aloga provided a better trace (this is liberty btw):

http://paste.openstack.org/show/592513/

So this query is getting back deleted instances (instances.deleted value is != 0 in the database):

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/liberty-eol/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L1891

That's because that query reads deleted instances by default, and apparently we have a deleted instances with the SOFT_DELETED vm_state somehow.

Anyway, later on when we try to update the instance in this flow, to set the 'cleaned' attribute on the instance in the libvirt driver, it blows up with InstanceNotFound because the instance is actually deleted.

I'm not sure how the instances got into this state, but we probably do need to clean them up so that the volumes/networking/resource tracking can all do it's thing in this flow.

I'll say I really don't like SOFT_DELETED as a feature, it's pretty gross and it's not tested in our CI system, but it is what it is I guess.
didn't see OOM in the bug report, why this could lead to OOM?
should you add a loop here to reclaim all instances?
These will be reclaimed in the next iteration of the periodic task, therefore a loop is not needed.

Looking at the DB API for this (instance_get_all_by_filters_sort) it returns deleted instances by default:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/80385a22ee480a4c9775148d4729ab5d9c52e76d/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L2086

We could filter out deleted instances from the DB API query:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/80385a22ee480a4c9775148d4729ab5d9c52e76d/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L2183-L2208

By just adding deleted=False to the filters dict above.

Wouldn't that be easier than messing with already-deleted instances? I still don't understand how we can get into a state where the instance is both deleted and SOFT_DELETED at the same time. Do you maybe have some external scripts/tooling that hard-deletes instances in the nova DB after they are soft deleted for some certain amount of time (effectively what this periodic is meant to do).

> Wouldn't that be easier than messing with already-deleted
 > instances? I still don't understand how we can get into a state

Being honest, 3 years later, I do not know. Maybe it was easier to go as you suggest, but probably something was wrong  (as I remember that this was not so straightforward), but who knows. After such a long time everything (including the DB) has changed.
This is really a separate fix that shouldn't have anything to do with the deleted InstanceNotFound bug you're trying to fix. I'd remove this from this change and fix it separately if necessary.

This is what I most hate from code review, as I had to adjust this basically because somebody (John) requested it in the past.

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/323250/23/nova/compute/manager.py@6520

This should be called out in the commit message.

If I'm reading the stacktrace in the bug report correctly, the issue is that way down in the libvirt driver's cleanup method it updates the instance and saves it, which fails when the instance is (soft) deleted (not to be confused with being in the SOFT_DELETED state).

Your fix here is to also read deleted SOFT_DELETED instances but I'm not sure how it could be both deleted and SOFT_DELETED since once it's reclaimed the vm_state should change to DELETED (in the _delete_instance method) and that would mean it shouldn't come back in the filtered query above.

So how is it possible to get into this state?
I do not know. Our database does not have any external tooling that modifies it, therefore this was something caused by nova.

nova/api/openstack/compute/volumes.py.message:
This patch changes the existing api behavior, and this case is not defined as microversion exception on our rule.

According to the bug report, this problem has appeared since v2.20. So I am fine if this behavior change happens on v2.20+.

I don't agree that we need a microversion for this change. This code was clearly written before the 2.20 use case. I don't think one should have to use microversion 2.20+ to view the volumes attached to a server. We should just check if the instance is in shelved_offloaded state and if so, ignore this 404 case.
I agree, we can't change the behaviour here for all the versions.

The one issue might be that for show it looks like our api-ref docs don't list device as optional. However, I think we could still return the field, but just set to None since that is totally legitimate for the 2.20 case.

I am not sure why we need this code.
If assigned_mountpoint is None, the 'device' should be None by calling _translate_attachment_detail_view() without this code.

yea this seems consistent. 

other way i was thinking not to append 'device' is no mountpoint like LIST does. But that makes SHOW API inconsistent between instance in SHELVED_OFFLOADED and other state.

even it is inconsistent with LIST API, looks fine to me.

non-None is being checked after server is unshelved. It used to assert when server was in shelved_offload state where no device attached to server.

tempest tests did not add that check before server unshelve because this API used to 400 in that case.

Now I am a little confused..
The corresponding Tempest test requires "non None" on this cases(shelve and shelved-offload) for microversion 2.20+ like https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/3b46d27c90aa6289724f4c137a0838c89d116b62/tempest/api/compute/volumes/test_attach_volume.py#L241

but this patch allows None on the response. Maybe now the Tempest test doesn't run on shelved-offload case on the gate actually, and this patch can pass.
_translate_attachment_detail_view()  does not include 'device' is mountpoint is None. here we should always return 'device'(with none in case of shelved_offload) for consistency.
yea +1 on returning it always and with None if no mountpoint as done in this change

I see your saying, but I don't agree with adding None as 'device' for consistency only. According to the code, 'device' doesn't appear intentionally on a response.

 230
 231     d['serverId'] = instance_uuid
 232     if mountpoint:
 233         d['device'] = mountpoint  <HERE>
 234
 235     return d

And there is a lot of inconsistency on Nova API and we cannot fix it without microversion bumps in general.

This check goes way back 5 years:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7406/

And makes really no sense why this is here. It actually looks like an uncaught mistake as a result of a refactor.

Before 2.20 you can't get a bdm without a device name if it's attached to the server, because we set it in the API when we create the bdm record. So this check made no sense, and I don't think it's something you could hit, or as a user need to code around. I really don't think we need to consider this codified into the API. It was just never a problem until it became a real use case with 2.20, but we can fix that with a simple vm_state check.
We need to return the device key to be backward compatible with the response, since Tempest probably validates that. There is no contract on the value.

nova/api/openstack/compute/attach_interf.message: This is being used as a translation for a generic NeutronClientException which could be anything - we don't necessarily know that it's a 400. What if we're getting that because neutron is down or something failed in the neutron server? Returning a 400 in that case isn't correct since it should be a 500. I think we likely need some more specific error handling in the code that is raising this exception to determine if it's a 400 or what.

nova/exception.py.message: The error raised by Neutron is an general exception, nothing specific to the creation of a port

nova/network/neutronv2/api.py.message: This is too broad to be translated to what is handled as a 400 response in the API. Couldn't this be handling some kind of BadRequest exception or checking the code in the exception to determine if a BadRequest should be raised? In the bug the error from neutron is "BadRequest Bad request: VM with ports belonging to subnets across enter prises is not allowed in VSP" so is that a 400 from neutronclient?
